questions.question: Growth in plants is defined as an irreversible permanent increase in:
options: Weight due to water absorption only
Size, weight, and number of cells
questions.explanation: Growth is defined as an irreversible permanent increase in size of an organ or its parts or even of an individual cell. This increase is accompanied by increase in weight and number of cells through cell division. (NCERT Page 166)

questions.question: Plants retain the capacity for unlimited growth throughout their life due to:
questions.explanation: Plants retain the capacity for unlimited growth throughout their life because they possess meristems at certain locations in their body. These meristems have the capacity to divide and self-perpetuate. (NCERT Page 166)

questions.question: The type of growth where new cells are continuously added to the plant body throughout life is called:
questions.explanation: This ability of plants to continuously grow throughout their life is called 'open form of growth' or indeterminate growth. Animals generally have 'closed form' or determinate growth. (NCERT Page 166)

questions.question: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of phases in cell growth?
questions.explanation: The three phases of growth are: Cell division (meristematic phase), Cell elongation, and Cell maturation (differentiation). These occur in sequence from apical meristem downwards. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: Root apical meristem and shoot apical meristem together are known as:
questions.explanation: Root apical meristem (RAM) and shoot apical meristem (SAM) together are called primary meristems. They are responsible for primary growth leading to increase in length of plants. (NCERT Page 166)

questions.question: The increase in girth of stem and root in dicot plants is due to:
questions.explanation: Lateral meristems (vascular cambium and cork cambium) appear later in life and cause the increase in girth of organs. This is called secondary growth and occurs mainly in dicot plants. (NCERT Page 166)

questions.question: Growth in plants is measurable and can be measured by various parameters. Which of the following is NOT typically used to measure plant growth?
questions.explanation: Growth in plants can be measured by increase in fresh weight, dry weight, length, area, volume, and cell number. Chlorophyll content is not a direct measure of growth. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: In the meristematic phase of growth, cells:
options: Are rich in protoplasm with large vacuoles
Have thin cellulose walls and dense cytoplasm
questions.explanation: In the meristematic phase, cells are rich in protoplasm, possess large conspicuous nuclei, have thin cellulose cell walls, and dense cytoplasm. They divide repeatedly. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: The phase of growth characterized by cell enlargement, increased vacuolation, and new cell wall deposition is:
questions.explanation: The phase of elongation is characterized by cell enlargement, increased vacuolation, and new cell wall deposition. Cells proximal to the meristematic zone show this phase. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: In the phase of maturation, cells:
options: Attain maximum size and wall thickening
questions.explanation: In the maturation phase, cells attain their maximum size in terms of wall thickening and protoplasmic modifications. This phase is further away from the apex. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: If the length of a maize root at time t₀ is L₀ and at time t₁ is L₁, the growth rate is expressed as:
questions.explanation: Growth rate is expressed as growth per unit time. Mathematically, it is (L₁ - L₀)/t, representing the increase in growth per unit time. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: In arithmetic growth, one daughter cell continues to divide while the other:
questions.explanation: In arithmetic growth, following mitotic cell division, only one daughter cell continues to divide while the other differentiates and matures. This is seen in root elongation at constant rate. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: The mathematical expression for arithmetic growth is:
questions.explanation: In arithmetic growth, Lt = L₀ + rt, where Lt is length at time t, L₀ is length at time zero, r is growth rate, and t is time. This gives a linear increase. (NCERT Page 168)

questions.question: In geometric growth, the initial growth is:
questions.explanation: In geometric growth, the initial growth is slow (lag phase) but increases rapidly thereafter at an exponential rate. Both daughter cells following mitosis retain ability to divide. (NCERT Page 168)

questions.question: The exponential growth can be expressed as:
questions.explanation: Exponential growth is expressed as W₁ = W₀ × eʳᵗ, where W₁ is final size, W₀ is initial size, r is growth rate, t is time, and e is base of natural logarithms. (NCERT Page 168)

questions.question: The growth of a pollen tube is an example of:
questions.explanation: The elongation of roots at a constant rate is an example of arithmetic growth. Similarly, pollen tube growth shows arithmetic growth where growth rate remains constant. (NCERT Page 167)

questions.question: A sigmoid growth curve shows:
questions.explanation: A sigmoid or S-shaped growth curve shows three phases: lag phase (slow growth), log/exponential phase (rapid growth), and stationary phase (growth slows due to limiting factors). (NCERT Page 168)

questions.question: The stationary phase in sigmoid growth curve occurs due to:
questions.explanation: In the stationary phase of sigmoid growth, growth slows down due to limited nutrient supply. The organism reaches its maximum growth potential under given conditions. (NCERT Page 168)

questions.question: The relative growth rate (RGR) is expressed as:
options: Growth per unit initial parameter per unit time
Growth of given system per unit time only
Total growth divided by final weight
questions.explanation: Relative Growth Rate (RGR) is the growth of the given system per unit time expressed on a common basis like per unit initial parameter. It allows comparison between different organisms. (NCERT Page 168)

questions.question: Growth is influenced by both internal and external factors. Which is NOT an internal factor?
questions.explanation: Internal factors affecting growth include genetic factors, growth regulators, and nutrition (intrinsic factors). Temperature, light, CO₂, and water are external (extrinsic) factors. (NCERT Page 168)

questions.question: The cells derived from root apical meristem and shoot apical meristem undergo:
questions.explanation: Cells derived from root apical meristem and shoot apical meristem differentiate and mature to perform specific functions. This process of taking up permanent shape, size, and function is differentiation. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: Differentiation in plants involves:
options: Major structural changes in cell wall and protoplasm
questions.explanation: Differentiation involves major structural changes both in the cell wall and protoplasm of cells. These changes occur to enable cells to perform specific functions. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: The formation of tracheary elements involves:
options: Loss of protoplasm and lignification of cell walls
questions.explanation: Formation of tracheary elements involves loss of protoplasm and deposition of lignin in cell walls. Similarly, sieve tube elements lose nucleus at maturity. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: The process by which living differentiated cells regain the capacity to divide under certain conditions is called:
questions.explanation: Dedifferentiation is the process by which living differentiated cells (like parenchyma) regain the capacity for division under certain conditions. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: The formation of interfascicular cambium and cork cambium from fully differentiated parenchyma is an example of:
questions.explanation: The formation of interfascicular cambium and cork cambium from fully differentiated parenchyma cells is an example of dedifferentiation, where cells regain meristematic capacity. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: The dedifferentiated cells that divide and produce cells that lose the capacity to divide but mature to perform specific functions exhibit:
questions.explanation: Redifferentiation occurs when products of dedifferentiated cells lose the capacity to divide again but mature to perform specific functions. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: The formation of secondary xylem and secondary phloem by vascular cambium is an example of:
questions.explanation: The formation of secondary xylem and secondary phloem by vascular cambium (a dedifferentiated tissue) is an example of redifferentiation. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: Development in plants refers to:
options: All changes from seed germination to senescence
questions.explanation: Development is the sum total of growth and differentiation. It includes all changes that an organism goes through during its life cycle from germination to senescence. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: Plant development is considered as the sum of:
questions.explanation: Development is considered as the sum total of growth and differentiation. Plants follow different pathways in response to environment or phases of life to form different structures. (NCERT Page 169)

questions.question: Heterophylly observed in cotton, coriander, and larkspur is due to:
questions.explanation: Heterophylly (different shaped leaves) in cotton, coriander, and larkspur is due to different phases of life (juvenile vs adult). The leaves produced during juvenile and mature phases are different. (NCERT Page 170)

questions.question: Heterophylly in buttercup is due to:
questions.explanation: In buttercup (Ranunculus), heterophylly is due to different environments. Leaves submerged in water are dissected while those on surface are broad with lobes. (NCERT Page 170)

questions.question: The ability of plants to follow different pathways in response to environment or phases of life to form different kinds of structures is called:
questions.explanation: Plasticity is the ability of plants to follow different pathways in response to environment or phases of life to form different kinds of structures. Heterophylly is an example. (NCERT Page 170)

questions.question: Plant growth regulators (PGRs) can be defined as:
options: Small simple molecules with diverse actions
questions.explanation: Plant Growth Regulators (PGRs) are small, simple molecules of diverse chemical composition. They could be indole compounds, adenine derivatives, terpenoids, or gases like ethylene. (NCERT Page 170)

questions.question: Charles Darwin and his son Francis Darwin observed phototropism in:
questions.explanation: Charles Darwin and Francis Darwin observed phototropism in coleoptiles of canary grass. They observed that the coleoptile tip was the site of perception of light stimulus. (NCERT Page 170)

questions.question: According to Darwin's experiment, the coleoptile tip:
options: Is the site of light perception and transmits influence to lower part
questions.explanation: Darwin concluded that the coleoptile tip is the site of transmitting some 'influence' to the lower part when exposed to unilateral light. The tip perceives light and influences growth below. (NCERT Page 170)

questions.question: F.W. Went first isolated auxin from:
questions.explanation: F.W. Went (1928) first isolated auxin from oat coleoptile tips. He placed coleoptile tips on agar blocks and showed the diffusible substance caused curvature. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: The 'Avena curvature test' was developed by:
questions.explanation: F.W. Went developed the Avena curvature test using oat (Avena) coleoptiles to bioassay auxin activity. The degree of curvature is proportional to auxin concentration. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: The term 'auxin' was coined by:
questions.explanation: F.W. Went coined the term 'auxin' from Greek 'auxein' meaning 'to grow'. He isolated this diffusible substance from coleoptile tips. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: The most common naturally occurring auxin is:
questions.explanation: IAA (Indole-3-acetic acid) is the most common naturally occurring auxin. IBA is also natural, while NAA and 2,4-D are synthetic auxins. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Which of the following is a synthetic auxin?
questions.explanation: NAA (Naphthalene acetic acid) and 2,4-D (2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid) are synthetic auxins. IAA and IBA are naturally occurring auxins. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Auxin is synthesized primarily at:
questions.explanation: Auxin is generally produced by growing apices of stems and roots, from where it migrates to the regions of its action. Shoot tips and young leaves are major sites. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: The phenomenon where apical bud inhibits the growth of lateral buds is called:
questions.explanation: Apical dominance is the phenomenon where the presence of apical bud (which produces auxin) inhibits the growth of lateral buds. Removal of apical bud promotes lateral bud growth. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Auxins promote:
questions.explanation: Auxins promote cell elongation in the shoot region and also help in cell division (when applied along with cytokinins in tissue culture). (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Auxins induce initiation of roots in:
questions.explanation: Auxins induce initiation of roots in stem cuttings, a property widely used in horticulture for vegetative propagation of plants. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Auxins promote flowering in:
questions.explanation: Auxins promote flowering in pineapples. They are also used to induce parthenocarpy (seedless fruit development) in tomatoes. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: The development of fruit without fertilization induced by auxins is called:
questions.explanation: Parthenocarpy is the development of fruit without fertilization. Auxins can induce parthenocarpy in tomatoes, resulting in seedless fruits. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: 2,4-D is widely used as:
questions.explanation: 2,4-D (2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid) is widely used as herbicide to kill dicot weeds. It doesn't affect mature monocot plants due to different anatomical features. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Auxins are involved in:
questions.explanation: Auxins play a role in both phototropic (response to light) and geotropic (response to gravity) responses through differential distribution. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: The 'foolish seedling' disease (Bakanae disease) of rice is caused by:
questions.explanation: Bakanae (foolish seedling) disease of rice is caused by the fungus Gibberella fujikuroi. E. Kurosawa (1926) observed that sterile filtrates of this fungus caused symptoms. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: E. Kurosawa (1926) observed the symptoms of Bakanae disease caused by:
questions.explanation: E. Kurosawa observed that sterile filtrates of the fungus Gibberella fujikuroi could produce symptoms of Bakanae disease, proving a chemical substance was responsible. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: The active substance causing Bakanae disease was later identified as:
questions.explanation: The active substance was later identified as gibberellic acid (GA). Gibberellins were named after the fungus Gibberella fujikuroi from which they were first isolated. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: How many gibberellins are known to exist today?
questions.explanation: More than 100 gibberellins are reported from widely different organisms such as fungi and higher plants. They are denoted as GA₁, GA₂, GA₃, etc. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: Gibberellins are acidic in nature and are chemically:
questions.explanation: Gibberellins are weakly acidic. They are all terpenoids (compounds made from acetate units via the mevalonic acid pathway). (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of gibberellins?
options: Elongation of internodes in genetically dwarf plants
Promotion of seed and bud dormancy
Mobilization of food reserves during seed germination
questions.explanation: Gibberellins break seed and bud dormancy, not promote it. They cause internode elongation in dwarf plants, induce bolting, and mobilize food reserves during germination. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: GA₃ can cause the stem of genetically dwarf pea plants to elongate to normal height. This property is used in:
questions.explanation: GA₃ increases the length of grape stalks and promotes stem elongation. In sugarcane, it increases the length of the stem, thereby increasing yield. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: The rapid elongation of internodes just prior to flowering in rosette plants is called:
questions.explanation: Bolting is the rapid elongation of internodes just prior to flowering in rosette plants like beet, cabbage, and henbane. Gibberellins induce bolting. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: Gibberellins promote early seed production in:
questions.explanation: Gibberellins can hasten maturity period in juvenile conifers, thus leading to early seed production. They also promote flowering in some plants. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: During seed germination, gibberellins stimulate production of enzymes like:
questions.explanation: During germination, gibberellins stimulate the production of various hydrolytic enzymes including α-amylases, lipases, and proteases to mobilize stored food reserves. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: The brewing industry uses gibberellins for:
questions.explanation: Gibberellins are used in the brewing industry to speed up the malting process by stimulating α-amylase production in barley seeds. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: Cytokinins were discovered by:
questions.explanation: Skoog and Miller discovered and named cytokinins. They identified kinetin from autoclaved herring sperm DNA and later zeatin from corn (maize). (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: Kinetin was isolated from:
questions.explanation: Kinetin was isolated from autoclaved herring sperm DNA. It does not occur naturally in plants but has cytokinin-like activity. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: The natural cytokinin zeatin was isolated from:
questions.explanation: Zeatin, the first naturally occurring cytokinin, was isolated from corn (Zea mays) kernels and immature corn. It is named after Zea mays. (NCERT Page 172-173)

questions.question: Cytokinins are synthesized in:
options: Regions of rapid cell division like root apices
questions.explanation: Cytokinins are synthesized in regions where rapid cell division occurs, for example, root apices, developing shoot buds, young fruits. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: The primary function of cytokinins is to promote:
questions.explanation: Cytokinins primarily promote cytokinesis (cell division), especially when present along with auxins. They are named after this function. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Cytokinins help in overcoming:
questions.explanation: Cytokinins help overcome apical dominance by promoting the growth of lateral buds. They counteract the inhibitory effect of auxin from the apical bud. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Cytokinins delay senescence of leaves. This is called:
questions.explanation: The ability of cytokinins to delay leaf senescence is called the Richmond-Lang effect. They promote nutrient mobilization to treated areas. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Cytokinins promote nutrient mobilization. This helps in:
questions.explanation: Cytokinins promote nutrient mobilization, which helps in delaying senescence of leaves. Nutrients move to areas with high cytokinin concentration. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Ethylene is unique among plant hormones because it is:
questions.explanation: Ethylene is unique because it is a simple gaseous hormone (C₂H₄). It was the first gaseous plant hormone discovered. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Ethylene is synthesized from:
questions.explanation: Ethylene is synthesized in large amounts by tissues undergoing senescence and ripening fruits. It is synthesized from the amino acid methionine. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: The horizontal growth of seedlings, swelling of the axis, and apical hook formation is called:
questions.explanation: Triple response to ethylene includes: (1) inhibition of stem elongation, (2) increase in thickness of stem (swelling), and (3) transverse orientation of stem (horizontal growth). (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Ethylene promotes:
questions.explanation: Ethylene is widely used to promote ripening of climacteric fruits like apples, bananas, and tomatoes. It hastens fruit ripening. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Ethylene promotes senescence and abscission of:
options: Plant organs like leaves and flowers
questions.explanation: Ethylene promotes senescence and abscission of plant organs especially leaves and flowers. It accelerates the natural aging process. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Ethylene is highly effective in:
questions.explanation: Ethylene is highly effective in inducing flowering in pineapple. It also promotes female flower formation in cucurbits. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Fruits that show a sudden rise in respiration rate during ripening are called:
questions.explanation: Climacteric fruits show a sudden rise in respiration rate (respiratory climacteric) during ripening. Examples include apple, banana, mango. Ethylene promotes this process. (NCERT Page 173)

questions.question: Abscisic acid (ABA) is also known as:
questions.explanation: Abscisic acid (ABA) is called the stress hormone because it increases plant tolerance to various stresses. It also inhibits growth and metabolism. (NCERT Page 174)

questions.question: ABA acts as a growth inhibitor and:
options: Inhibits seed germination and induces dormancy
questions.explanation: ABA acts as a general plant growth inhibitor, inhibits seed germination, and induces dormancy. It also stimulates closure of stomata during water stress. (NCERT Page 174)

questions.question: ABA stimulates closure of stomata in:
questions.explanation: ABA stimulates the closure of stomata in the epidermis of leaves. This helps reduce water loss during stress conditions. (NCERT Page 174)

questions.question: ABA increases the tolerance of plants to:
questions.explanation: ABA increases the tolerance of plants to various kinds of stresses including drought, cold, and salinity. Hence it's called the stress hormone. (NCERT Page 174)

questions.question: Plant growth regulators that promote plant growth are called:
questions.explanation: Plant growth promoters include auxins, gibberellins, and cytokinins. They promote cell division, cell enlargement, flowering, fruiting, and seed formation. (NCERT Page 174)

questions.question: Which of the following acts as both growth promoter and inhibitor depending on concentration?
questions.explanation: Ethylene is placed in a separate category as it can be both growth promoter and inhibitor depending on its concentration and the plant part. (NCERT Page 174)

questions.question: Photoperiodism is the response of plants to:
options: Relative lengths of day and night
questions.explanation: Photoperiodism is the response of plants to the relative lengths of day and night (photoperiod). It affects flowering in many plants. (NCERT Page 175)

questions.question: Plants requiring long day photoperiod for flowering are called:
questions.explanation: Long day plants (LDP) require long day photoperiod (light period exceeding a critical duration) to flower. Examples include henbane and wheat. (NCERT Page 175)

questions.question: Short day plants flower when:
options: Light period is less than critical length
Light period is equal to dark period
questions.explanation: Short day plants (SDP) require light period less than a critical length to flower. Examples include tobacco, soybean, and chrysanthemum. (NCERT Page 175)

questions.question: Plants that flower regardless of the duration of light are called:
questions.explanation: Day neutral plants can flower regardless of the duration of light exposure. Examples include tomato and cotton. (NCERT Page 175)

questions.question: The role of low temperature in flowering is called:
questions.explanation: Vernalization is the phenomenon where exposure to low temperature promotes flowering in certain plants. Some plants require cold treatment to flower. (NCERT Page 175)

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of vernalization?
options: Winter wheat requiring cold treatment to flower
questions.explanation: Winter wheat requires vernalization (cold treatment) for flowering. Plants are exposed to low temperature (0-5°C) for a period to acquire the ability to flower. (NCERT Page 175)

questions.question: Seed dormancy can be broken by:
questions.explanation: Seed dormancy can be broken by gibberellin application. Gibberellins overcome the inhibitory effect of ABA on seed germination and break dormancy. (NCERT Page 172)

questions.question: The antagonistic relationship between ABA and gibberellins is seen in:
questions.explanation: ABA and gibberellins show antagonistic effects in seed dormancy. ABA promotes dormancy while gibberellins break dormancy and promote germination. (NCERT Page 174)

questions.question: The ratio of auxin to cytokinin determines:
options: Root and shoot differentiation in tissue culture
questions.explanation: In tissue culture, high auxin:cytokinin ratio promotes root formation while low ratio promotes shoot formation. Equal ratio promotes callus formation. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Which hormone pair is involved in apical dominance?
questions.explanation: Apical dominance involves auxin (promoting dominance from apical bud) and cytokinin (promoting lateral bud growth). They have antagonistic effects. (NCERT Page 171, 173)

questions.question: Auxin causes elongation of cells in stem but inhibits growth in:
questions.explanation: Auxin promotes cell elongation in stems but at higher concentrations inhibits root growth. This differential sensitivity explains geotropism. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: The movement of auxin from shoot tip to base is called:
questions.explanation: Auxin shows polar transport - basipetal (from tip to base) in shoots. This polarity is maintained by auxin carrier proteins and is crucial for its functions. (NCERT Page 171)

questions.question: Female flowers in cucumbers can be increased by application of:
questions.explanation: Ethylene promotes female flower formation in cucurbits like cucumber. It also induces flowering in pineapples. (NCERT Page 173)
